<@U0SHX06QZ|pm> has joined the channel
Sup guys! I was wondering what your opinions were on greenDAO?
<https://github.com/greenrobot/greenDAO>

attachments.title: greenrobot/greenDAO
attachments.text: greenDAO is a light & fast ORM solution for Android that maps objects to SQLite databases.

text: <@U06CMRAC9>: We evaluated using it for some of our projects but opted for Sugar ORM due to easy of use and lack of documentation on GreenDAO at the time. After using Sugar for a while, one of my colleagues found some shortfalls and developed a lightweight ORM that we’re using in 4 production projects. It’s called CPOrm <https://github.com/Wackymax/CPOrm>

attachments.title: Wackymax/CPOrm
attachments.text: CPOrm - Content Provider Orm - This is a little orm that functions by using android content providers

text:
I'll be sure to check it out! 

I'm gauging my options right now, I hate dealing with sqlite directly
Cool, let me know what you think of it. We also hate working with any SQL directly.

<@U06CMRAC9>: just keep in mind that not working with SQLite directly might cause you problems. Basically you lose flexibility by not dealing with it directly. If you don't have any too complex databases then you should be fine with ORM technologies. Personally I use pure SQLite and make custom SQL Views for some more complex queries.
Anyone tried out realm yet? <https://realm.io>

attachments.title: Realm is a mobile database: a replacement for SQLite & Core Data
attachments.text: Realm is a mobile database: a replacement for SQLite & Core Data. It can save you thousands of lines of code & weeks of work, and lets you craft amazing new user experiences.
attachments.fallback: Realm is a mobile database: a replacement for SQLite & Core Data

text: While we’re on the topic of dbs
I’ve heard good things about it. Before people said that it wasn’t async but they just added that feature
the problem is the requirement of getters and settings prevent immutable objects combined with the inability to create custom methods on the data objects
those are its biggest complaints, otherwise it works very well
Same. They also released a new version last week that finally allows you to implement interfaces and methods to our objects etc.

I’m trying to use NumberPicker, for a hour & minutes input. The scrolling speed is so slow. To get from 1 to 30 takes way too long. I found something that looks promising to change, `private static final int SELECTOR_MAX_FLING_VELOCITY_ADJUSTMENT = 8;` but I can’t because of final
what’s the best solution?
still, not possible to have a collection of primitives, boxed or unboxed, because every model has to extend a realmobject which is annoying
I’ve found both DBFlow (<https://github.com/Raizlabs/DBFlow>) and StorIO (<https://github.com/pushtorefresh/storio>) to be good ORM solutions. StorIO if you are using RxJava, DBFlow otherwise.

attachments.title: Raizlabs/DBFlow
attachments.text: DBFlow - A blazing fast, powerful, and very simple ORM android database library that writes database code for you.

attachments.title: pushtorefresh/storio
attachments.text: storio - Beautiful API for SQLiteDatabase and ContentResolver

Is injecting a presenter into another presenter considered ok ?
why do you need to do that?
that sounds like mvp incenst lol
I know.. It sounds like that to me too
Thats why I had to ask :simple_smile:
we did that once
viewpager scenario I think
onboarding
slides horizontally
I would only do that if one of my presenters felt lonely
they were!
Well I have 1 view overlapping a map - and I need to draw something on that map.
you could hear them sobbing when it compiled
and the MapPresenter holds all the logic
:scream:
So your view overlapping it is receiving the input? As in drawing a line
Ah well no
It’s the GUI for calculating a route on that map
and I get back a list of coordinates, which the map knows how to draw
I see, so you basically have data on the overlapping view that the underlying view needs to know
correct?
Yes
Then just shoot them over
eventbus, broadcast, anything you want
Gotcha. Allready using an eventbus for the purpose
I just dont like it :simple_smile:
then the best thing to do would be to save that data in a centralized place (just an in-memory model) -> hide the overlaying view -> signal the underlying view that there is data to be processed
so: `OverlayingPresenter#saveDataToModel()` and `UnderlyingPresenter#getDatafromModel()` something like that anyway
Maybe. Eventbus sounds cleaner and less prone to bugs, just hate maintaining all the event classes
Personally I don't use eventbus because I don't like it's flow
I like having more control over the flow of data
Another idea is to create a custom view of everything together and have one presenter manage the whole thing
Also the overlaying view has its own ObjectGraph created with dagger - so I can’t inject the service directly either
to use something like a `Subject` that the map can subscribe to

Ladies and Gentleman, heres the deal: On the following scenario: a Fragment that uses both MVVM (Model-View-ViewModel) and the DataBinding framework.

I have a RecyclerView that has an Adapter for N ViewModels which hold an instance for the actual Model.

When I click on my View, through Databinding it reflects to my "startDownload" method on my ViewModel. Thats ok till now. My "startDownload" is called from the ViewModel, passing to the "doDownload" method my Model instance. How should I work here that, if my model changes (I'm downloading something so I want the totalDownloadedBytes to be refreshed), the ViewModel knows it and "notifyPropertyChanged" is called, so that the UI is actually according to my Model?
